Facts of the case

In 2010, for the first time in over forty years, Wisconsin voters elected a Republican majority in the state assembly and the senate, and a Republican governor.

Facts of the Case
The case involves a challenge to Wisconsin's 2011 state legislative redistricting plan, known as Act 43, which was enacted by a Republican-controlled legislature and signed into law by a Republican governor.

Conclusion
The plaintiffs failed to demonstrate Article III standing, so there is no need to resolve any of the questions presented.
sentence_results.best_match:
Conclusion/Holding
The Supreme Court held that the plaintiffs failed to demonstrate Article III standing because they did not prove that they suffered a particularized injury.

sentence_results.ground_truth_sentence: In a unanimous decision authored by Chief Justice John Roberts, the Court sidestepped (for now) all of the key issues regarding partisan gerrymandering, resolving the case instead on the technical issue of judicial standing.
sentence_results.best_match: Specifically, the Court considered whether the plaintiffs had suffered a particularized injury due to the alleged partisan gerrymandering and whether their claimed harm was sufficiently concrete and individualized to satisfy Article III standing requirements.

sentence_results.ground_truth_sentence: For a plaintiff to bring a case in federal court, she must have Article III standing, which requires showing three elements, one of which is "injury in fact."
sentence_results.best_match:
Conclusion/Holding

sentence_results.ground_truth_sentence: To show injury in fact, a plaintiff must show that she has suffered "invasion of a legally protected interest" that is "concrete and particularized."
